text.p: The chief executive and president of Gucci Group N.V. said Friday he was comfortable with analysts' consensus estimate for fiscal 1997 earnings of $3.35 per share.
"We are comfortable with the estimate," Domenico De Sole told Reuters in a telephone interview from Florence, Italy. The luxury goods company recorded earnings of $2.76 a share in fiscal 1996.
He declined to discuss the consensus estimate of $3.90 a share for fiscal 1998.
Gucci reported Thursday that first-quarter sales rose 31.5 percent from a year earlier, to $254.3 million, beyond the company's expectations.
Gucci's American Depositary Receipts were up one at 69-1/2 after falling 5-7/8 in heavy trade Thursday.
De Sole said Gucci's results were "absolutely excellent, especially since the first quarter includes April, which was a weak month for the industry."
De Sole said Gucci had been hurt by a weaker yen that cut into purchases by Japanese consumers.
"The yen went down dramatically and that slowed down the travel by Japanese customers. That has an impact on the entire luxury industry," he said.
The April weakness in sales could extend "for the next couple of months," but the recent strengthening of the yen could help revenues, he said.
On April 1 De Sole told Reuters he was comfortable with analysts' estimate that Gucci would earn $3.30 a share for fiscal 1997.
He provided the $3.35 figure to Reuters today.
